explanation:
Correct calculation: \(10\,\text{cm} \times 3\,\text{cm} = 30\,\text{cm}^2\)

Student's calculation: Likely \(10\,\text{cm} \times 3\,\text{cm} \div 2 = 15\,\text{cm}^2\)

The student correctly identified the base (10 cm) and perpendicular height (3 cm) but erroneously divided the product by 2. This stems from conflating the area formulas for parallelograms (base × height) and triangles (base × height ÷ 2). The error specifically occurs at the final operation, where an unwarranted halving was applied. This distinguishes it from using slant height (which would yield 10 × 4 = 40) or other listed misconceptions about triangular area calculations. The core issue is misapplying a formula from a similar shape rather than using incorrect dimensions.
